35 % in fraction = 7/20 because 35 / 5 = 7 and 100 / 5 = 20. 0.64  in fraction = 16/25 because 64/4 = 16 and 100/4 = 25.  82% in decimal = 0.82 we just need to place the , 2 step in left side. 4/5 in decimal = 0.8 we just need to find how to set the denominator to 10 by multiplying the numerator and denominator with the same number and then move the , one step in left.  14/50 in percentage = 28% you first need to have it in the decimal value so 14 / 50 is 0.28 then you need to multiply this number per 100. 0.19 in percentage = 19% you just need to multiply this number per 100 because you already have the decimal value.

Elaborate sir. 35% can also be 35/100. How did you figure out that you needed to divide 35 with 5 ?

@kazziodex9561    To simplify a fraction, you need to divide both the numerator (the top number) and the denominator (the bottom number) by their greatest common divisor (GCD).  The GCD is the largest number that divides both the numerator and the denominator without leaving a remainder. Here's a step-by-step guide on how to do this:  For example, if you have the fraction 35/100 ​, 35 is the numerator and 100 is the denominator.  List the factors of both the numerator and the denominator : Factors of 35: 1, 5, 7, 35 Factors of 100: 1, 2, 4, 5, 10, 20, 25, 50, 100 The common factors are: 1, 5 The greatest common factor is 5.  Divide both 35 and 100 by 5. So, 35/100​ simplifies to 7/20​.  If the numerator is a prime number and it doesn't divide the denominator, the fraction is already in its simplest form.  so you know that you cannot do more simple than that because 7 is a prime number, so that's how you manage to get the same number to divide with. I think I figured it out. I hope this helps.  35% = 7/20 is just 35÷5/100÷5, because if you multiply 7 and 20 by 5 then they become 35 and 100.  0.64 = 16/25 because 64÷4/100÷4 are 16 and 25. Same thing as above.  This means that if you answered 35/100 and 64/100 (like me) then you're technically correct, it's just that your answer is rounded up to 100.

To convert a decimal to a fraction:  - Count the number of digits on the right side of the decimal point.  - Remove the decimal point from the original number.  - Place this new number without a decimal point on the numerator of a fraction whose denominator is 1 followed by the same number of zeroes as there were digits on the right side of the decimal point in the original number.  - Simplify the fraction. For example, to convert 4.56 to a fraction, we should observe that there are 2 digits on the right side of the decimal point. Then, we can remove the decimal point from 4.56 to get 456, and then divide 456 by 1 followed by 2 zeroes (that is, by 100). Then we simplify the fraction 456/100 to get 114/25, by dividing the numerator and the denominator of the fraction each by 4.  To convert a percentage to a fraction, if the percentage is a whole number, you can simply place that whole number over 100 in a fraction and simplify the fraction. If the percentage is not a whole number, you can convert the percentage to a decimal number and then convert it to a fraction using the previous steps. I hope this helps!

'Units' is another name for 'ones digit'. It is the place value that the single digit whole numbers occupy. I hope this helps!

3/5 is simple an example Dave is using to demonstrate converting fractions to percentages. 1/5 is used because you can get the answer for 3/5 as a percentage by adding the value for 1/5 as a percentage 3 times (because 1/5 + 1/5 + 1/5 = 3/5). Neither of these numbers are related to the example in the table of 3/10. I hope this helps!

Then we simplify the fraction 456/100 to get 114/25, by dividing the numerator and the denominator of the fraction each by 4.  To convert a percentage to a fraction, if the percentage is a whole number, you can simply place that whole number over 100 in a fraction and simplify the fraction. If the percentage is not a whole number, you can convert the percentage to a decimal number and then convert it to a fraction using the previous steps. I hope this helps!

When you multiply both the numerator and denominator of a fraction by another whole number, the resulting fraction is equivalent to the fraction you started off with. For example, imagine a pizza cut into 4 slices, and imagine that only 1 slice of 4 has mushrooms on it. That is, 1/4 slices has mushroom. Then, imagine cutting every slice into 2 slices. Now, the whole pizza has 8 slices, so we have multiplied the total number of slices of pizza by 2, and the slice with mushrooms has also been cut into two slices, so the number of slices with mushrooms has been multiplied by 2. Now, we have 2/8 slices with mushroom on. But, since we have not added or taken away any mushroom from the pizza, these fractions, 1/4 and 2/8, must be equivalent. This is because both the numerator and denominator have been multiplied by 2. In Dave's example, he multiplies the numerator and denominator of 21/50 by 2 because he wants an equivalent fraction whose denominator is 100, so that he can compare its size to the fraction 45/100. In the cases of 11/16 and 5/8, there is no reason to multiply the numerator and denominator by any other number. I hope this helps!

To convert a decimal to a fraction:  - Count the number of digits on the right side of the decimal point.  - Remove the decimal point from the original number.  - Place this new number without a decimal point on the numerator of a fraction whose denominator is 1 followed by the same number of zeroes as there were digits on the right side of the decimal point in the original number.  - Simplify the fraction. For example, to convert 4.56 to a fraction, we should observe that there are 2 digits on the right side of the decimal point. Then, we can remove the decimal point from 4.56 to get 456, and then divide 456 by 1 followed by 2 zeroes (that is, by 100). Then we simplify the fraction 456/100 to get 114/25, by dividing the numerator and the denominator of the fraction each by 4.  To convert a percentage to a fraction, if the percentage is a whole number, you can simply place that whole number over 100 in a fraction and simplify the fraction. If the percentage is not a whole number, you can convert the percentage to a decimal number and then convert it to a fraction using the previous steps. I hope this helps!

There are a few common tricks with division that are helpful to keep in mind when doing exercises like the ones in the video. The one dave uses in this case is that a whole number can be divided by 10 if and only if it has 0 in the ones digit (or the unit place). For example, 30, 100, and 2570 can all be divided by 10 because they have a 0 in the ones digit (these divisions return 30/10 = 3, 100/10 = 10, 2570/10 = 257), but 6, 41, and 832 cannot be divided by 10. Additionally, you can get the answer to these divisions by simply removing the 0 in the ones digit and shifting all of the other digits to the right. In the example, Dave does this on the numerator and the denominator of the fraction to simplify it. Here are some similar tricks that you might find helpful!  - A whole number can be divided by 2 if and only if it has an even number (0, 2, 4, 6, or 8) in its ones digit (that is, a whole number can be divided by 2 if and only if it is an even number).  - A whole number can be divided by 5 if and only if it has a 0 or a 5 in its ones digit. I hope this helps!

@ProfessorDaveExplains     I was a little rushed when writing my earlier comment, so please allow me to clarify what I meant.  To adults, who 'learned' mathematics many years ago, these terms are synonymous.    To a child, who is currently learning mathematics, using the term 'reduce' can cause confusion because it implies a change in value.  I was looking for a video that I could share with my students, and the fact that this video used outdated/imprecise language meant that I immediately ruled it out for potential classroom use.  If you'd like to learn more about why current mathematics educators use simplify, here is a short blog post I found: https://greatminds.org/math/blog/eureka/post/precise-fraction-language  Additionally, the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics has published a number of useful articles over the years about language that math teachers should not use because it causes conceptual errors in our students. Kids can take us quite literally at times, and if we want to build up the correct conceptual understanding, then we need to use precise language.  I hope this explains my earlier comment -- I wish you all the best in your future videos!

An elastic band of length 15cm can be stretched without breaking by increasing its length by between 58% and 62%. Once stretched the elastic band will not return to its original length, it will have increased by 10% of the length it was stretched by. I have stretched the elastic band to 24cm.
